Award.AwardTitle: Fast Spectral Methods and their Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is to design accurate, fast and robust spectral methods for solving a large class of partial differential equations, and apply them to investigate several important problems of current interest. More precisely, it is proposed to develop (i) adaptive sparse spectral methods for solving a class of higher-dimensional problems; (ii) spectrally-accurate schemes in space-time for a class of parabolic type PDEs; (iii) robust and accurate spectral methods for electromagnetic scattering, particularly for layered medium and with higher wave numbers; and (iv) to apply the proposed fast and accurate spectral methods to investigate emerging problems in fluid dynamics and materials science such as drop formation & filament breakup and ferroelectric & multiferroic nanostructures in advanced materials processing.

It is expected that the proposed numerical simulations will enable us to handle challenging problems having stringent accuracy and/or memory requirements with a reasonable cost in CPU and turn-around time, contribute towards better understandings of the complex physical and mathematical problems, and provide valuable information for the design of advanced materials and on the rheological and hydrodynamic properties of complex fluids. Another important goal of this project is to engage graduate students in learning necessary skills of computational and applied mathematics so that they can pursue a successful career in sciences and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project is to design, analyze and implement fast and robust spectral methods for solving a class of partial differential equations which are difficult to solve numerically.

With the support of this grant, we developed a number of efficient algorithms for solving a class of partial differential equations, and appliedthem to investigate several important problems of current interest.More precisely, we developed (i)  efficient sparse spectral methods for solving higher-dimensional problems and applied them to solve electronic Schrodinger equation; (ii)  energy   stable schemes for a class of phase-field models for multiphase flows, including two-phase flows with large density ratios, two-phase flows with dynamic moving contact lines, complex fluids such as mixture of nematic crystals with a Newtonian fluid; (iii) efficient numerical schemes for incompressible flows with outflow boundary conditions and for fluid-solid interactions; (iv) robust and accurate spectral methods forelectromagnetic scattering, including transmission eigenvalue problems and related inverse problems;  (v) stable and fast algorithms for Fokker-Planck equation of FENE dumbbell model, and (vi)  fast and accurate spectralmethods  to investigateferroelectric &  multi-ferroic nano-structures in advanced materials processing.


The numerical algorithms we developed in this project  enable usto handle challenging problems having stringent accuracy and/or memoryrequirements with a reasonable cost in CPU and turn-around time, contribute towards better understandings of the complex physical andmathematical problems, and provide valuable information for the design of advanced materials and on the rheological and hydrodynamic properties of complex fluids.


 The project also provided   graduate  students with opportunities in learning necessaryskills of computational and applied mathematics so that they can pursue a successful career in science and engineering.
